texts.orig: network
texts.text: network

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's no secret that I'm a big fan of the  Routerboard  devices and the  RouterOS software from Mikrotik  that runs on them. The hardware is solid, the software is stable and feature-rich, and I found a  great vendor  that ships quickly.
texts.text: It's no secret that I'm a big fan of the  Routerboard  devices and the  RouterOS software from Mikrotik  that runs on them. The hardware is solid, the software is stable and feature-rich, and I found a  great vendor  that ships quickly.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I recently added a  RB493G  ( ~ $230 USD ) to sit in front of a pair of colocated servers. The majority of the setup routine was the same as with my previous devices except for the IPv6 configuration.
texts.text: I recently added a  RB493G  ( ~ $230 USD ) to sit in front of a pair of colocated servers. The majority of the setup routine was the same as with my previous devices except for the IPv6 configuration.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In the past, I've set up IPv6 tunnels with  Hurricane Electric  and it's been mostly a cut-and-paste operation from the sample configuration in their IPv6 tunnel portal. Setting up native IPv6 involved a little more legwork.
texts.text: In the past, I've set up IPv6 tunnels with  Hurricane Electric  and it's been mostly a cut-and-paste operation from the sample configuration in their IPv6 tunnel portal. Setting up native IPv6 involved a little more legwork.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If your provider will give you two /64's or an entire /48, getting IPv6 connectivity for your WAN/LAN interfaces is simple. However, if you can only get one /64, you'll have to see if your provider can route it to you via your Mikrotik's  link local  interface (I wouldn't recommend this for many reasons).
texts.text: If your provider will give you two /64's or an entire /48, getting IPv6 connectivity for your WAN/LAN interfaces is simple. However, if you can only get one /64, you'll have to see if your provider can route it to you via your Mikrotik's  link local  interface (I wouldn't recommend this for many reasons).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I split my Mikrotik into two interfaces: wan and lanbridge. The lanbridge bridge joins all of the LAN ethernet ports (ether2-9 on the RB493G) and the wan interface connects to the upstream switch.
texts.text: I split my Mikrotik into two interfaces: wan and lanbridge. The lanbridge bridge joins all of the LAN ethernet ports (ether2-9 on the RB493G) and the wan interface connects to the upstream switch.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My configuration:
texts.text: My configuration:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
/ipv6 address
add address=2001:DB8:0:1::2/64 advertise=yes disabled=no eui-64=no interface=wan
add address=2001:DB8:0:2::1/64 advertise=yes disabled=no eui-64=no interface=lanbridge
/ipv6 route
add disabled=no distance=1 dst-address=::/0 gateway=2001:DB8:0:1::1 scope=30 \
  target-scope=10
/ipv6 nd
add advertise-dns=no advertise-mac-address=yes disabled=no hop-limit=64 \
  interface=all managed-address-configuration=no mtu=unspecified \
  other-configuration=no ra-delay=3s ra-interval=3m20s-10m ra-lifetime=30m \
  reachable-time=unspecified retransmit-interval=unspecified
/ipv6 nd prefix default
set autonomous=yes preferred-lifetime=1w valid-lifetime=4w2d
texts.text:
/ipv6 address
add address=2001:DB8:0:1::2/64 advertise=yes disabled=no eui-64=no interface=wan
add address=2001:DB8:0:2::1/64 advertise=yes disabled=no eui-64=no interface=lanbridge
/ipv6 route
add disabled=no distance=1 dst-address=::/0 gateway=2001:DB8:0:1::1 scope=30 \
  target-scope=10
/ipv6 nd
add advertise-dns=no advertise-mac-address=yes disabled=no hop-limit=64 \
  interface=all managed-address-configuration=no mtu=unspecified \
  other-configuration=no ra-delay=3s ra-interval=3m20s-10m ra-lifetime=30m \
  reachable-time=unspecified retransmit-interval=unspecified
/ipv6 nd prefix default
set autonomous=yes preferred-lifetime=1w valid-lifetime=4w2d

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Explanation:
texts.text: Explanation:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
/ipv6 address
add address=2001:DB8:0:1::2/64 advertise=yes disabled=no eui-64=no interface=wan
add address=2001:DB8:0:2::1/64 advertise=yes disabled=no eui-64=no interface=lanbridge
texts.text:
/ipv6 address
add address=2001:DB8:0:1::2/64 advertise=yes disabled=no eui-64=no interface=wan
add address=2001:DB8:0:2::1/64 advertise=yes disabled=no eui-64=no interface=lanbridge

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: These two lines configure the IPv6 addresses for the firewall's interfaces. My provider's router holds the 2001:DB8:0:1::1/64 address and routes the remainder of that /64 to me via 2001:DB8:0:1::2/64. The second /64 is on the lanbridge interface and my LAN devices take their IP addresses from that block. My provider routes that second /64 to me via the 2001:DB8:0:1::2/64 IP on my wan interface.
texts.text: These two lines configure the IPv6 addresses for the firewall's interfaces. My provider's router holds the 2001:DB8:0:1::1/64 address and routes the remainder of that /64 to me via 2001:DB8:0:1::2/64. The second /64 is on the lanbridge interface and my LAN devices take their IP addresses from that block. My provider routes that second /64 to me via the 2001:DB8:0:1::2/64 IP on my wan interface.

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
/ipv6 route
add disabled=no distance=1 dst-address=::/0 gateway=2001:DB8:0:1::1 scope=30 \
  target-scope=10
texts.text:
/ipv6 route
add disabled=no distance=1 dst-address=::/0 gateway=2001:DB8:0:1::1 scope=30 \
  target-scope=10

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've set a  gateway  for IPv6 traffic so that the Mikrotik knows where to send internet-bound IPv6 traffic (in this case, to my ISP's core router).
texts.text: I've set a  gateway  for IPv6 traffic so that the Mikrotik knows where to send internet-bound IPv6 traffic (in this case, to my ISP's core router).

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
/ipv6 nd
add advertise-dns=no advertise-mac-address=yes disabled=no hop-limit=64 \
  interface=lanbridge managed-address-configuration=no mtu=unspecified \
  other-configuration=no ra-delay=3s ra-interval=3m20s-10m ra-lifetime=30m \
  reachable-time=unspecified retransmit-interval=unspecified
/ipv6 nd prefix default
set autonomous=yes preferred-lifetime=1w valid-lifetime=4w2d
texts.text:
/ipv6 nd
add advertise-dns=no advertise-mac-address=yes disabled=no hop-limit=64 \
  interface=lanbridge managed-address-configuration=no mtu=unspecified \
  other-configuration=no ra-delay=3s ra-interval=3m20s-10m ra-lifetime=30m \
  reachable-time=unspecified retransmit-interval=unspecified
/ipv6 nd prefix default
set autonomous=yes preferred-lifetime=1w valid-lifetime=4w2d

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: These last two lines configure the  neighbor discovery  on my lanbridge interface. This allows my LAN devices to do  stateless autoconfiguration  (which gives them an IPv6 address as well as the gateway).
texts.text: These last two lines configure the  neighbor discovery  on my lanbridge interface. This allows my LAN devices to do  stateless autoconfiguration  (which gives them an IPv6 address as well as the gateway).
